qas.question: What is name of the function used for the largest integer not greater than the number in question?
For what size natural number does Bertrand's postulate hold?
How is the prime number p in Bertrand's postulate expressed mathematically?
On what theorem is the formula that frequently generates the number 2 and all other primes precisely once based on?
What is the name of the function used for the smallest integer not greater than the number in question?
For what size natural number does Chebyshev's postulate hold?
How is the prime number p in Chebyshev's postulate expressed mathematically?
On what theorem is the formula that frequently generates the number 2 and all other primes precisely twice based on?

context: are prime for any natural number n. Here  represents <a0_0><b5_0>the <a0_1><a0_2><a0_3><a0_4>floor<a0_2/><a0_1/> function<b5_0/><a0_4/><a0_3/><a0_0/>, i.e., largest integer not greater than the number in question. The latter formula can be shown using Bertrand's postulate (proven first by <a1_0><a1_1><a1_2><a1_3><a1_4><b6_0>Chebyshev<b6_0/><a1_4/><a1_3/><a1_2/><a1_1/><a1_0/>), which states that there always exists at least one prime number p with <a3_0><a3_1><a3_3><a3_4><b8_0>n < p < 2n − 2<b8_0/><a3_4/><a3_3/><a3_1/><a3_0/>, for <a2_0><b7_0>any natural number <a2_1><a2_2><a2_4>n <a2_3>> 3<b7_0/><a2_4/><a2_2/><a2_1/><a2_0/>.<a2_3/> However, computing <a3_2>A or μ<a3_2/> requires the knowledge of infinitely many primes to begin with. Another formula is based on <a4_0><a4_1><a4_2><a4_3><a4_4><b9_0>Wilson's<a4_2/><a4_1/> theorem<b9_0/><a4_4/><a4_3/><a4_0/> and generates the number 2 many times and all other primes exactly once.
